text: OF PRACTICE, MAKING FINDINGS,

label: HH1

text: DESIST ORDER
label: HH1

text: The Securities and Exchange Commission (“Commission”) deems it appropriate that public
label: BODY

text: administrative and cease-and-desist proceedings be, and hereby are, instituted against Altschuler,
label: BODY

text: Melvoin and Glasser LLP and  G. Victor Johnson, II, CPA (the “Respondents”) pursuant to
label: BODY

text: Section 203(k) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 (“Advisers Act”), Section 4C1 of the
label: BODY

text: 1 Section 4C provides that:
label: BODY

text: The Commission may censure any person, or deny, temporarily or permanently, to any person the privilege
label: BODY

text: of appearing or practicing before the Commission in any way, if that person is found . . . “(1) not to possess the
label: BODY

text: requisite qualifications to represent others (2) to be lacking in character or integrity, or to have engaged in unethical
label: BODY

text: Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (“Exchange Act”) and Rule 102(e)(1)(ii) of the Commission’s
label: BODY

text: Rules of Practice.2
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH1

text: In anticipation of the institution of these proceedings, the Respondents have each submitted
label: BODY

text: an Offer of Settlement (the “Offers”), which the Commission has determined to accept.  Solely for
label: BODY

text: the purpose of these proceedings and any other proceedings brought by or on behalf of the
label: BODY

text: Commission, or to which the Commission is a party, and without admitting or denying the findings
label: BODY

text: herein, except as to the Commission’s jurisdiction over the Respondents and the subject matter of
label: BODY

text: these proceedings, which are admitted, Respondents consent to the entry of this Order Instituting
label: BODY

text: Public Administrative and Cease-and-Desist Proceedings Pursuant to Section 4C of the Securities
label: BODY

text: Exchange Act of 1934, Section 203(k) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 102(e) of
label: BODY

text: the Commission’s Rules of Practice, Making Findings, and Imposing Remedial Sanctions and a
label: BODY

text: Cease-and-Desist Order (“Order”), as set forth below.
label: BODY

text: III.
label: HH1

text: On the basis of this Order and the Respondents’ Offers, the Commission finds3 that:
label: BODY

text: SUMMARY
label: HH1

text: This matter concerns the roles of audit firm Altschuler, Melvoin and Glasser LLP
label: BODY

text: (“Altschuler”) and engagement partner George Victor Johnson, II (“Johnson”) in violations of
label: BODY

text: Section 206(4) of the Advisers Act and Rule 206(4)-2 (the “Custody Rule”) under the Advisers
label: BODY

text: Act by Sentinel Management Group, Inc. (“Sentinel”), a registered investment adviser.  At the
label: BODY

text: relevant time, 2002 through 2006, Sentinel was required by the Custody Rule to have an
label: BODY

text: independent public accountant verify all client funds and securities by surprise examination at
label: BODY

text: least once each calendar year.  Altschuler was the independent public accounting firm that
label: BODY

text: Sentinel retained to perform its surprise examinations from 2002 through 2006, and Johnson was
label: BODY

text: the engagement partner at Altschuler overseeing the Sentinel surprise examinations for every
label: BODY

text: year except 2004.4   The Respondents negligently failed to conduct the examinations in
label: BODY

text: accordance with the professional standards applicable to examinations under Advisers Act Rule
label: BODY

text: 206(4)-2, thereby causing Sentinel’s violations of the Custody Rule and Section 206(4) of the
label: BODY

text: or improper professional conduct; or (3) to have willfully violated, or willfully aided and abetted the violation of,
label: BODY

text: any provision of the securities laws or the rules and regulations thereunder.”
label: BODY

text: 2 Rule 102(e)(1)(ii) provides, in relevant part, that:
label: BODY

text: The Commission may censure or deny, temporarily or permanently, the privilege of appearing or practicing
label: BODY

text: before it … to any person … who is found … to have engaged in improper professional conduct.
label: BODY

text: 3 The findings herein are made pursuant to the Respondents' Offers of Settlement and are not binding on any other
label: BODY

text: person or entity in this or in any other proceeding.
label: BODY

text: 4 Johnson did not act as the engagement partner for 2004 because Johnson and Altschuler, without admitting or
label: BODY

text: denying its findings, consented in June 2005, to the entry of an order, which required Johnson to refrain from
label: BODY

text: serving as an engagement partner in any audit of any CFTC registrant for six months. See In the Matter of G. Victor
label: BODY

text: Johnson and Altschuler, Melvoin and Glasser, LLP, CFTC Docket No. 04-29 (June 13, 2005).
label: BODY

text: Advisers Act. The conduct related to the exams also constituted improper professional conduct
label: BODY

text: pursuant to Section 4C(b)(2) of the Exchange Act and Rule 102(e)(1)(ii) of the Commission’s
label: BODY

text: Rules of Practice.
label: BODY

text: RESPONDENTS
label: HH1

text: Altschuler, Melvoin and Glasser LLP is an Illinois limited liability partnership that
label: HH1

text: maintained its principal place of business in Chicago, Illinois.  Altschuler performed annual
label: BODY

text: Advisers Act surprise examinations for Sentinel, a registered investment adviser, for the years
label: BODY

text: 2002 through 2006 and also served as Sentinel’s independent auditor from 2002 through 2005.
label: BODY

text: On November 1, 2006, Altschuler sold most of its assets to another public accounting firm and is
label: BODY

text: now in liquidation.  Altschuler is, however, contractually required to complete any pending
label: BODY

text: engagements, sign-off on report reissuance and consents, and defend malpractice claims.
label: BODY

text: George Victor Johnson, II, CPA age 69, of Arlington Heights, Illinois is a certified
label: HH1

text: public accountant licensed in Illinois and currently a director of a public accounting firm.
label: BODY

text: Johnson served as the engagement partner for the 2002, 2003, 2005 and 2006 Advisers Act
label: BODY

text: surprise examinations of Sentinel and the 2002 through 2005 financial statement audits of
label: BODY

text: Sentinel on behalf of Altschuler.
label: BODY

text: OTHER RELEVANT ENTITY
label: HH1

text: Sentinel Management Group, Inc. (SEC File No. 801-15642) is an Illinois corporation
label: HH1

text: based in Northbrook, Illinois, that has been registered with the Commission as an investment
label: BODY

text: adviser since 1980.  Sentinel is registered with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as a
label: BODY

text: futures commission merchant.  On August 17, 2007, Sentinel filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.  At
label: BODY

text: the time of Sentinel’s bankruptcy, Sentinel managed approximately 180 accounts for around 70
label: BODY

text: clients and had approximately $1.4 billion in assets under management.
label: BODY

text: FACTS
label: HH1

text: The Commission’s Action Against Sentinel
label: BODY

text: Prior to its bankruptcy on August 17, 2007, Sentinel primarily managed
label: BODY

text: investments of short-term cash for advisory clients, including futures commission merchants,
label: BODY

text: hedge funds, financial institutions, pension funds, and individuals.   Sentinel purported to invest all
label: BODY

text: of its clients’ assets in pooled investment vehicles (the “Securities Pools”) 5 and to hold the
label: BODY

text: underlying securities in three segregated accounts at a qualified custodian bank (the “Custodian”).
label: BODY

text: Sentinel obtained a loan, for its own benefit, from the Custodian and
label: BODY

text: established a collateral account at the Custodian to maintain securities pledged as collateral for this
label: BODY

text: loan. During the relevant period, the loan from the Custodian to Sentinel was similar to a line of
label: BODY

text: credit in that it fluctuated on a daily basis.  The outstanding balance of the loan grew significantly
label: BODY

text: from when Altschuler first began performing Advisers Act surprise examinations for Sentinel to
label: BODY

text: the days leading up to Sentinel’s bankruptcy.  For example, the loan balance was approximately
label: BODY

text: 5 Advisory clients owned pro-rata, undivided interests in the Securities Pools.
label: BODY

text: $20 million at December 31, 2002, approximately $120 million at December 31, 2004, and
label: BODY

text: approximately $230 million at December 31, 2006.  On August 20, 2007, the Commission filed an
label: BODY

text: emergency enforcement action against Sentinel in the United States District Court in Illinois
label: BODY

text: alleging multiple violations of the antifraud provisions of the Advisers Act.  According to the
label: BODY

text: Commission’s complaint against Sentinel, Sentinel misused Securities Pools’ securities to
label: BODY

text: collateralize the loan. When Sentinel collapsed in August 2007, the Custodian claimed ownership
label: BODY

text: of several hundred million dollars in Securities Pool securities that had been improperly held in
label: BODY

text: Sentinel’s account to collateralize the loan made by the Custodian to Sentinel for the benefit of
label: BODY

text: Sentinel. On December 17, 2008, the court entered a judgment by consent against Sentinel
label: BODY

text: permanently enjoining it from violating the antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws.
label: BODY

text: Altschuler’s and Johnson’s Unreasonable Advisers Act Surprise Examinations
label: BODY

text: Caused Sentinel’s Violations of the Custody Rule
label: BODY

text: Section 206(4) of the Advisers Act prohibits investment advisers from
label: BODY

text: engaging in “any act, practice, or course of business which is fraudulent, deceptive, or
label: BODY

text: manipulative,” as defined by the Commission by rule.  During the relevant period, Rule 206(4)-2
label: BODY

text: stated in pertinent part that it constitutes a fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative act, practice or
label: BODY

text: course of business within the meaning of Section 206(4) of the Advisers Act for any registered
label: BODY

text: investment adviser to have custody of client funds or securities unless a qualified custodian or the
label: BODY

text: adviser sends a quarterly account statement to each of the clients for which it maintains funds or
label: BODY

text: securities, or to each beneficial owner of a pooled investment vehicle, identifying the amount of
label: BODY

text: funds and of each security in the account at the end of the period and setting forth all transactions
label: BODY

text: in the account during the period.6  If the adviser sends the quarterly account statements itself,
label: BODY

text: which Sentinel did, an independent public accountant generally must verify all of the funds and
label: BODY

text: securities by actual examination at least once during each calendar year on a date chosen by the
label: BODY

text: accountant without prior notice to the investment adviser (a “surprise examination”). 7
label: BODY

text: The Commission provided guidance for accountants conducting surprise
label: BODY

text: examinations in Accounting Series Release No. 1038 which indicates, among other things, that the
label: BODY

text: accountant should express an opinion as to whether the investment adviser was in compliance with
label: BODY

text: Rule 206(4)-2(a)(1) as of the examination date. Rule 206(4)-2(a)(1) requires, among other things,
label: BODY

text: client assets of which the adviser has custody to be maintained by a qualified custodian (i) in a
label: BODY

text: separate account for each client under that client’s name or (ii) in accounts that contain only [the
label: BODY

text: adviser’s] clients’ funds and securities, under [the adviser’s] name as agent or trustee for the
label: BODY

text: clients.
label: BODY

text: 6 Prior to the effectiveness of the 2003 amendments to Rule 206(4)-2, Rule 206(4)-2 was not materially different
label: BODY

text: with regard to those parts of the rule relevant to the violations at issue in this matter.
label: BODY

text: 7 Rule 206(4)-2(b)(3) provided an exception from the surprise examination requirement for a pooled investment
label: BODY

text: vehicle if certain criteria were met, including, among other things, a financial-statement audit of the pool.  This
label: BODY

text: provision, however, is not relevant here because the Securities Pools were not audited.
label: BODY

text: 8 Statement of the Commission describing nature of examination required to be made of all funds and securities held
label: BODY

text: by an investment adviser and the content of related accountant's certificate, Accounting Series Release No. 103,
label: BODY

text: Investment Advisers Act Release No. 201 (May 26, 1966) (“ASR No. 103”).
label: BODY

text: During the relevant period, Sentinel was required to undergo surprise
label: BODY

text: examinations by an independent public accountant. 9  To conduct an appropriate examination under
label: BODY

text: Rule 206(4)-2, an accountant should have, among other things:10
label: BODY

text: Confirmed all Securities Pool securities held by the Custodian.
label: BODY

text: Reconciled all securities between the Custodian’s records and the adviser’s
label: BODY

text: records of the client accounts.
label: BODY

text: Conducted the examination by “surprise.”
label: BODY

text: Completed the surprise examination in accordance with U.S. Generally
label: BODY

text: Accepted Auditing or Attestation Standards as established by the American
label: BODY

text: Institute of Certified Public Accountants (“AICPA Attest
label: BODY

text: Standards”)(emphasis added).
label: BODY

text: Rule 206(4)-2 also states that the accountant is to transmit to the
label: BODY

text: Commission, within 30 days after the completion of the examination, a certificate, attached to a
label: BODY

text: Form ADV-E, stating that an examination of such funds and securities has been made, and
label: BODY

text: describing the nature and extent of the examination.
label: BODY

text: The AICPA also provided guidance concerning the examination and
label: BODY

text: reporting requirements of Rule 206(4)-2 in the AICPA Audit and Accounting Guide: Audits of
label: BODY

text: Investment Companies (“AICPA Guide”). The AICPA Guide contained an illustrative attestation
label: BODY

text: report for independent public accountants for surprise examinations performed pursuant to Rule
label: BODY

text: 206(4)-2.11  According to the AICPA Guide, the attestation report should, if applicable, include
label: BODY

text: specific references to the following procedures performed by the independent accountant in
label: BODY

text: connection with the surprise examination: (1) confirmation of all cash and securities held by a third
label: BODY

text: party, such as a custodian bank or broker, in the name of the investment adviser as agent or trustee
label: BODY

text: for clients; and (2) reconciliation of all such cash and securities to books and records of client
label: BODY

text: accounts maintained by the investment adviser.  These procedures were applicable to the Sentinel
label: BODY

text: surprise examinations. Additionally, the illustrative attestation report contained an opinion on
label: BODY

text: management’s assertion regarding compliance with, among other things, Rule 206(4)-2(a)(1) based
label: BODY

text: on the aforementioned procedures.
label: BODY

text: 9 Prior to Nov. 5, 2003, the Custody Rule required all registered advisers to have surprise examinations. See
label: BODY

text: Advisers Act Release No. 2176 (Sept. 25, 2003) (amending the rule).  Thus, Sentinel was required to have the
label: BODY

text: Securities Pools’ assets verified by surprise examination under the Custody Rule, as it existed prior to Nov. 5, 2003.
label: BODY

text: It also was required to have surprise examinations after the rule’s amendment in 2003 because it, not its custodian,
label: BODY

text: sent account statements to the investors in the Securities Pools. See Rule 206(4)-2(a)(3)(iii) (the account statements
label: BODY

text: required to be sent under Paragraph (a)(3)(ii) of the Rule must be sent to each beneficial owner of a pooled
label: BODY

text: investment vehicle). The Commission amended Rule 206(4)-2 in December 2009 to require registered investment
label: BODY

text: advisers with custody of client assets to have surprise examinations annually, subject to certain exceptions, as well
label: BODY

text: as require that qualified custodians holding those assets send out account statements.  See Advisers Act Release No.
label: BODY

text: 2968 (Dec. 30, 2009).  Unless otherwise noted, references to the Rule refer to its provisions as it existed prior to its
label: BODY

text: most recent amendment.
label: BODY

text: 10 See Rule 206(4)-2; ASR No. 103 and Advisers Act Release No. 2176 (Sept. 25, 2003).
label: BODY

text: 11 See, e.g., paragraph 11.12 of the AICPA Audit and Accounting Guide, Audits of Investment Companies, with
label: BODY

text: conforming changes as of May 1, 2002.
label: BODY

text: While conducting these examinations, Altschuler and Johnson negligently
label: BODY

text: failed to meet the AICPA attestation standard requiring “due professional care.”  See AT 101A.39
label: BODY

text: (AICPA 2002).  For example, Johnson knew in 2002 of Sentinel’s loan from the Custodian.  He
label: BODY

text: also was informed that Sentinel regularly transferred securities, originally purchased for the
label: BODY

text: Securities Pools, from segregated accounts held at the Custodian to Sentinel’s collateral account at
label: BODY

text: the Custodian.  In addition, Altschuler and Johnson obtained documents from the Custodian
label: BODY

text: during each of the surprise examinations (e.g., collateral account statement confirmations from the
label: BODY

text: Custodian) that reflected securities purportedly owned by the Securities Pools were held in
label: BODY

text: Sentinel’s collateral account at the Custodian, which Johnson knew or should have known also
label: BODY

text: contained Sentinel owned securities.  Although the collateral account statements they received
label: BODY

text: from the Custodian were in Sentinel’s name and the securities in the account were not marked for
label: BODY

text: the benefit of the Securities Pools, Altschuler and Johnson included the securities in this account in
label: BODY

text: their reconciliations of the Custodian’s records to the Adviser’s records. Altschuler and Johnson
label: BODY

text: should have recognized that Sentinel was holding some securities purportedly owned by the
label: BODY

text: Securities Pools in a Sentinel account at the Custodian and that such practice did not comply with
label: BODY

text: Rule 206(4)-2(a)(1).  Moreover, certain securities were shown in Sentinel’s records as being held
label: BODY

text: in the Securities Pools’ segregated accounts, whereas such securities were shown in the
label: BODY

text: Custodian’s records as being held only in Sentinel’s collateral account.  The examination work
label: BODY

text: papers further reveal that Altschuler and Johnson obtained certain schedules (including account
label: BODY

text: statements of investors in the Securities Pools) that showed Sentinel was using as collateral for its
label: BODY

text: loan certain Securities Pools’ securities which were maintained in Sentinel’s collateral account,
label: BODY

text: commingled with Sentinel’s own assets.
label: BODY

text: Nonetheless, based primarily on oral statements from Sentinel’s
label: BODY

text: management, Altschuler and Johnson had reached the conclusion that Sentinel owned the securities
label: BODY

text: used to collateralize the loan, contrary to certain documentary evidence in the examination work
label: BODY

text: papers and elsewhere, and therefore they failed to follow up adequately on the inconsistencies or to
label: BODY

text: design procedures to discover whether the Securities Pools’ securities were being commingled.
label: BODY

text: In addition, from 2002-2006, Johnson (for every year other than 2004) and
label: BODY

text: Altschuler issued unqualified attestation opinions that stated that Sentinel’s assertions regarding its
label: BODY

text: compliance with Rule 206(4)-2(a)(1) for the examination periods were fairly stated in all material
label: BODY

text: respects. However, as a result of procedures performed and evidence obtained, Altschuler and
label: BODY

text: Johnson should have known that Sentinel was not complying with Rule 206(4)-2(a)(1) because
label: BODY

text: Sentinel was commingling the Securities Pools’ securities in its collateral account.  Therefore,
label: BODY

text: Altschuler and/or Johnson should not have issued unqualified attestation opinions.
label: BODY

text: In addition, contrary to the Custody Rule, Altschuler and Johnson failed to
label: BODY

text: conduct all of their examinations of Sentinel by surprise either by providing prior notice of the
label: BODY

text: examination or in one instance allowing Sentinel to choose the date of the exam.
label: BODY

text: Finally, Johnson also failed to provide sufficient supervision to the
label: BODY

text: Altschuler staff members that were tasked to complete the surprise examinations.  Johnson billed
label: BODY

text: only 1.5 hours a year on the examinations and during that time provided little apparent guidance to
label: BODY

text: the staff members carrying out the examinations.  Such inadequate guidance and poor supervision
label: BODY

text: fall short of the requirement of the AICPA Attestation Standards’ first standard of field work that
label: BODY

text: “assistants, if any, shall be properly supervised.” See AT 101A.42 (AICPA 2002).
label: BODY

text: Altschuler and Johnson Engaged in Improper Professional Conduct
label: BODY

text: During the examinations of Sentinel from 2002 through 2006, the
label: BODY

text: Respondents engaged in improper professional conduct.
label: BODY

text: During each examination conducted, the Respondents (1) failed to
label: BODY

text: recognize that certain custodial-client securities (i.e., some of those of the Securities Pools) were
label: BODY

text: held in accounts that did not comply with subparagraph (a)(1) of Rule 206(4)-2 because such
label: BODY

text: securities were in Sentinel’s collateral account which was not marked as for the benefit of the
label: BODY

text: custodial clients (i.e., the Securities Pools); (2) failed to properly reconcile Sentinel’s Securities
label: BODY

text: Pool accounts to the account statements received directly from the Custodian; (3) inaccurately
label: BODY

text: stated in their opinions that Sentinel complied with subparagraph (a)(1) of Rule 206(4)-2; (4) failed
label: BODY

text: to conduct all of their examinations on a surprise basis; and (5) failed to file the examination report
label: BODY

text: within 30 days of completing the examinations.  The Respondents also failed to appreciate that
label: BODY

text: heightened scrutiny was warranted in connection with their examinations of Sentinel because of
label: BODY

text: the growing size of Sentinel’s loan from the Custodian, which resulted in Sentinel transferring
label: BODY

text: securities from the Securities Pools’ segregated accounts to its collateral account to collateralize its
label: BODY

text: loan.
label: BODY

text: The Respondents failed to conduct the examinations in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: AICPA Attestation Standards, which are the professional standards applicable to the examinations
label: BODY

text: performed under Advisers Act Rule 206(4)-2.
label: BODY

text: Section 4C of the Exchange Act and Rule 102(e)(1)(ii) provide that the
label: BODY

text: Commission may censure or temporarily or permanently deny an accountant the privilege of
label: BODY

text: appearing or practicing before it if it finds, after notice and opportunity for hearing, that the
label: BODY

text: accountant engaged in “improper professional conduct.”  In relevant part, Section 4C(b) and Rule
label: BODY

text: 102(e)(1)(iv) define ‘improper professional conduct’ to include either of the following two types of
label: BODY

text: negligent conduct:
label: BODY

text: (1) A single instance of highly unreasonable conduct that results in a violation of
label: BODY

text: applicable professional standards in circumstances in which an accountant, or a
label: BODY

text: person associated with a registered public accounting firm, knows, or should know,
label: BODY

text: that heightened scrutiny is warranted, or
label: BODY

text: (2) Repeated instances of unreasonable conduct, each resulting in a violation of
label: BODY

text: applicable professional standards, that indicate a lack of competence to practice
label: BODY

text: before the Commission.
label: BODY

text: FINDINGS
label: BODY

text: Based on the foregoing, the Commission finds that Altschuler and Johnson
label: BODY

text: caused Sentinel’s violations of Section 206(4) of the Advisers Act and Rule 206(4)-2 thereunder.
label: BODY

text: Based on the foregoing, the Commission finds that Altschuler and Johnson
label: BODY

text: engaged in improper professional conduct pursuant to Section 4C(b)(2) of the Exchange Act and
label: BODY

text: Rule 102(e)(1)(ii) of the Commission’s Rules of Practice.
label: BODY

text: IV.
label: HH1

text: In view of the foregoing, the Commission deems it appropriate to impose the sanctions
label: BODY

text: agreed to in the Respondents’ Offers.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, Pursuant to Sections 203(k) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940
label: BODY

text: (“Advisers Act”), and 4C of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (“Exchange Act”) and Rule
label: BODY

text: 102(e)(1)(ii) of the Commission’s Rules of Practice,  it is hereby ORDERED, effective
label: BODY

text: immediately, that:
label: BODY

text: Altschuler and Johnson shall cease and desist from causing any violations and any
label: BODY

text: future violations of Section 206(4) of the Advisers Act and Rule 206(4)-2
label: BODY

text: thereunder.
label: BODY

text: Altschuler is censured.
label: BODY

text: Johnson is denied the privilege of appearing or practicing before the Commission as
label: BODY

text: an accountant.
label: BODY

text: Altschuler shall within 7 days of the entry of this Order, pay disgorgement of
label: BODY

text: $18,700.00 in fees collected during the 2002 through 2006 Advisers Act
label: BODY

text: examinations and prejudgment interest of $5,476.00 to the Securities and Exchange
label: BODY

text: Commission. If timely payment is not made, additional interest shall accrue
label: BODY

text: pursuant to SEC Rule of Practice 600.  Payment shall be: (A) made by United
label: BODY

text: States postal money order, certified check, bank cashier's check or bank money
label: BODY

text: order; (B) made payable to the Securities and Exchange Commission; (C) hand-
label: BODY

text: delivered or mailed to the Office of Financial Management, Securities and
label: BODY

text: Exchange Commission, Operations Center, 6432 General Green Way, Stop 0-3,
label: BODY

text: Alexandria, VA 22312; and (D) submitted under cover letter that identifies
label: BODY

text: Altschuler as a Respondent in these proceedings, the file number of these
label: BODY

text: proceedings, a copy of which cover letter and money order or check shall be sent to
label: BODY

text: John Dugan, Division of Enforcement, Securities and Exchange Commission,
label: BODY

text: Boston Regional Office, 33 Arch Street, Boston, MA, 02110.
label: BODY

text: By the Commission.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Murphy

text: Service List
label: BODY

text: Rule 141 of the Commission's Rules of Practice provides that the Secretary, or another duly
